4427826/4347596/4453540.title: Seanscéal Eile a Bhaineas le Brigid Naofa
4427826/4347596/4453540.text:
Fadó fadó nuair a bhí Fionn agus na Fianna in Éirinn tháinig siad comh fada le Néiphin. Chuaidh siad ar a bhárr agus rinne siad bothán ann. D'fhan siad annsin ar feadh i bhfad agus sa deireadh rinne siad beagán cuireadóireachta. Maidin amháin bhí Fionn in a shuidhe go moch agus ar go brách leis go (Bun Dhá Abhainn - sin baile beag atá míle ó thuaidh ó'n sgoil seo.)Nuair a shroich sé an áit fuair sé piosa talmhan ó fhear annsin. Nuair a chonnaic Fionn an piosa talmhan
(continues on next page)

4428070/4374979/4457068.title: Finn Saves Tara
4428070/4374979/4457068.text: Long ago there used come a prince every year to burn Tara. Once Finn prepared to meet him, he had his father('s) spear that never misses its mark. When the prince was coming from the far hills of the north he was playing his magic harp with which he used to put the people of Tara to sleep.Finn flung his spear at him and killed him.

4460751/4377314/4460828.title: An Old Irish Tale - Fionn Mac Cumhaill
4460751/4377314/4460828.text:
An old Irish tale - Fionn Mac cumail.It is said that Fionn Mc Cuimail lived in Ballyin. When he was old he did not go hunting very often. One day he was hunting around Ballyin because there were forests growing there at that time.He saw a big high rock there and to give himself exercise he caught the stone, poised it on his little finger and threw it from Ballyin to where the Grove Gates in Lismore are now erected. Tis rock stand at a distances of about three miles from Ballyin.    Every visitor that comes to Lismore look at that rock, because the print of Fionn's five fingers are on that stone yet. People say it is said that Fionn Mc Cumail was the strongest man that was
(continues on next page)

ever in the world.An old irish tale of Fionn Mac cumail.Long ago, there lived in Ballyin an exceptionally strong man. His name was Fionn Mac Cumail. His chief occupation was hunting wild animals on the Knockmealdown Mountains. One day he was hunting the wild boar and wolf, with
(continues on next page)

4460751/4377317/4460837.title: An Old Irish Tale - Fionn Mac Cumhaill
4460751/4377317/4460837.text:
Fionn Mac Cumail was strolling through Leinster. He came to Glendalough. There he saw a lot of people gathered around  a stream.The King and Queen and Princess of Leinster were there.  Fionn heard the people saying that whoever could jump across the stream could marry the Princess.A few of the young men tried but none succeeded. Fionn tried and succeeded. The king did not know who Fionn was
(continues on next page)

4460751/4377319/4460841.title: An Old Irish Tale - Fionn Mac Cumhaill
4460751/4377319/4460841.text:
An Old Irish Tale Fionn Mac CumailFionn Mac Cumail and some of the Fianna went out every day hunting on the Knockmeal down mountain. One day they went out hunting and they saw a wild boar. To their surprise the boar ran away from them. None of them bothered about him but Fionn.      He hunted high and low but could not find this monstrous animal. A week past and he had not trace nor tiding of it. One morning Fionn went out earlier than usual and he saw his friend the boar. He followed it to its cave. The cave was to
(continues on next page)

4460751/4377321/4460845.title: An Old Irish Tale - Fionn Mac Cumhaill
4460751/4377321/4460845.text:
An old Irish tale - Fionn Mac CumailLong ago when Fionn Mc Cumail was in Ballyin Lismore every morning he washed himself at Droicead an Umair. He was so tall that when he bent down to wash himself his two legs were three mile apart. One was in Gleannrán and the other was in Srur. This was the basin where Fionn washed himself. It is still to be seen near the Glengarra School House. The bridge is over the Aba na Séad, and Umar can be seen under the bridge.When Fionn Mac Cumail lived in Ballyin Cormac Mar Airt was High King in Ireland ( 227-266 A.D.) Fionn was the king of the Fiannia. There was no bridge over the Aba na Séad at the time, but the big rock was there. Fionn hallowed a through out for himself in the centre of this rock which
(continues on next page)

4460751/4377326/4460855.title: An Old Irish Tale - Fionn Mac Cumhaill
4460751/4377326/4460855.text:
One day long ago Fionn Mac Cumhail was walking on the top of Cnoc Maol Domhnaigh Mountains. There were very huge rocks on the mountains-side and Fionn was tormented from stepping over them.It was a beautiful sunny day in summer. He was gazing up at the sky, and walking on at the same time. He never noticed a big rock beside his foot, and when he came to it, he struck the big toe of his right foot against it. This must have hurt him as he got into a temper.He gave the stone
(continues on next page)

4460751/4377328/4460864.title: An Old Irish Tale - Fionn Mac Cumhaill
4460751/4377328/4460864.text:
Fionn Mac Cumail used to take his morning's bath in a river called the Abha na Séad. A bridge is now built called the Umair Bridge over this place. Another Giant Eamman lived in Ballyin about a mile over the intervening hill.Eamman had the idea of killing Fionn in the bath. So one morning he started throwing stones over the hill. He did not succeed in killing Fionn. The farthest stone he threw is there still. It is now called Carraig Eamman.When Saint Declan was preaching in Ardmore Co. Waterford. He called the people around a well where he was going to baptise them. That well
(continues on next page)

4428064/4374300/4464543.title: Fionn Mac Cumhaill
4428064/4374300/4464543.text: Fionn Mc Cumaill was supposed to be a giant. It is said there was a test between himself and some other finians behind Neiphin at throwing rocks. Fionn took a big rock and threwn[sic] it across Neiphin and it fell in Terryduff. The rock is on the side of the road  yet and it is called Corraig a nine[?].

4427953/4360782/4464800.title: Columcille and his Mother's Sickness
4427953/4360782/4464800.text:
Once time Columcille's mother was very sick and every morning he used to ask her how she was. The first few mornings she said she was bad and he used to say "May you be worse tomorrow" Anyway on the third day she said "I am good thank God" and he said "May you be better". She was better and kept getting better until she was completely better. The reason he said "May you be worse" was because she did not show confidence in God.

4428114/4379486/4467124.title: Fionn Mac Cumhaill
4428114/4379486/4467124.text:
Bhí Fionn Mac Cumhal aon oíche amháin istig in tig áirthe agus chonaic sé braitlín deas isteach sa leaba agus bhí an-dhúil aige ann.D'imigh sé leis amach as an tigh. Bhí gabhar aige sa mbaile agus dhein sé an gabhar a mharbhughadh agus chuir sé an chroiceann air. Chuaidh sé go dtí an tig arís agus d'imigh sé síos an seimné agus bhí muintir an tighe ina chodladh. Thosnaigh sé ag déanamh glór agus d'éirigh muintir an tighe. Ghuid Finn isteach sa seomra agus ghuid sé an braitlín.



Bhí fear ann fadó gus bhí sé de bheús aige dul go dtí an baile mór gach lá. An oíche seo níor tháinigh sé abhaile. D'fhan sé san baile mór i dtigh a aintín.Bhí a aintín an-aosta agus bhí sí as a mheabhair agus gach aon rud a bhíodh aici thug sí don bhfear é an oíche seo. Thug sí dó an t-aon píosa amháin císte a bhí aici agus fuair sí bás leis an ocras.Tháinigh fear bocht go dtí an tórramh agus sé an rud a dúirt sé ná "Tabhair-se
(continues on next page)

4427991/4365145/4468173.title: An Prionsa a Cuireadh fá Gheasa
4427991/4365145/4468173.text:
Bhí rí in Éirinn fadó agus bhí sé pósta agus bhí mac amháin aige tógtha suas ina phrionnsa óg. Téigheadh sé amach ag suibhal dó féin gach lá. An lá seo nuair bhí sé amuich casadh bean leis agus d'fhiafruigh sí de an imreóchadh sé cluiche cardaí nó dísle.Dubhairt sé leis nach raibh a ghléas imeartha ar an mbaile leis. Dubhairt sise go raibh an gléas léithí féin. Tharraing sí amach slaitín draoidheachta agus rinne sí dhá chathaoireacha óir agus bord airgid agus chaith sí amach paca cardaí ar an mbord. Seárd a bhéas annseo ar sise an chéad duine a chuirfear an cluiche ar an duine eile chuirfeadh sé a geasa nó leigeadh sé dhó.D'imir síad ó láimh go láimh go dtí an lamh dheiridh agus d'eirigh leis an gcailín an cluiche a chur air. Dubhairt sé leithí a geasa a chur.
(continues on next page)

metadata.Teacher:: Pádraig Mag Shamhráin, Pádhraic Ó Gacháin

4427983/4363794/4469040.title: Diarmuid agus Gráinne
4427983/4363794/4469040.text:
(continued from previous page)
a raibh Diarmuid ag fágáil báis. An lá sin thug tarbh fiadháin buille dó agus bhí sé ag fághail báis. Da dtabharfadh Fionn deoch dó as a dhá láimh bheadh sé chomh maith is bhí sé ariamh.Cuaid Fionn faoi dhéin an uisge i dtosach agus thóg sé lán a dhá lamh ach nuair a bhí sé leath bealaigh cuimhnigh sé ar an rud a rinne Diarmuid agus Gráinne air agus chaith sé an tuisge uaidh. Pill sé arís faoi dhéin an uisge ach déirigh an rud céadhna. Phill sé an triomhadh h-uair agus bhí sé go díreach le taobh Diarmuid leis an uisge nuair a déag Diarmuid.Bhí brón mór ar Gráinne agus dimthigh sí lei ar fud an domhain ag cruinnuighadh a codach



Fionn in Árus na bhFir MoraLá amháin tháinig trí teachtaire ag Fionn agus dubhairt leis dhul comh fada le Árus na bhFir Móra go dtroideadh an Rí é.D’imtigh Fionn agus nuair a tháinig sé chomh fada leis an Árus cuireadh fáilte mór roimhe. Annsin cuireadh isteach chuig an Rí é agus nuair chonnaic an Rí é dubhairt sé “Céad fáilte roimh an fearín beag agus a mhadadh. Codlocaidh sibh ins an leabaidh céadhna liomsa. Annsin thóg an Rí Fionn agus leag sé é ar a láimh agus d’fág sé an madadh inaice leis. Annsin chuaidh siad ina chodhladh. Nuair a tháinig an oidhche chodhladh
(continues on next page)

4428027/4369648/4475696.title: Fionn, Oisín, Bran
4428027/4369648/4475696.text:
Fionn, Oisín 7 BranNuair a bhí na Fianna go léir i gcuideachtain bhí buachaill madaidh aca darab ainm Conán. Maidín amháin chuaidh sé amach ag tabhairt bidh do na madraí. Fuair sé coileán óg a thaithnigh go maith leis. "Beidh tusa i do mhadadh maith lá éigin" ar seisean. Annsin chuir sé an coileán in áit dó féin 7 thug sé aire maith dó ar feadh míosa.Nuair a bhí am mhí caithte chuir sé croiceann gabhair ar cheann mhaide céad troigh ar aoirde. Thug sé amach an coileán 7 chaith sé suas ar an chroiceann é. Choinnigh sé greim ar an gcroiceann.Nuair a chonnaic Conán seo thoisigh sé ag gáire. "Ní raibh mé amugha ar seisean nuair adubhairt
(continues on next page)

4428034/4370550/4476166.text:

The S. giant went home and he never came to Ireland again to challenge the I. giant because he was afraid he would be beaten by the I. giant.The forgetful manOne time a man was sitting beside the sea. He took out his pipe to have a smoke. He put the tobacco in the pipe and he took out a match and lit it. He held the match in his hand and threw the pipe put to sea.The tailor and the elephantOne time a circus was going about from town to town and they had some tame elephants. One day they settled in a town where they were to have a show the next day. There was a lake of dirty water outside the town. The elephant used to put his trunk in the window and people used to give him nice things to eat. He came along to a tailor's window and out in his trunk. One of the tailors gave him a stab of a needle instead of what he expected. The elephant went off as tight as he could to the lake of dirty water and he came back with his trunk filled. He put in the trunk and spattered all the clothes that were on the table inside the window. He went away again prouder than ever.

4428299/4392569/4476282.title: Fionn Mac Cumhaill agus Dearg Mór
4428299/4392569/4476282.text: Lá amháin bhí Fionn Mac Cumhail amuigh ag seilg ag Teamhair na Rioghtha. Casadh fear air a dtugadh siad an Dearg Mór air. Bhí cú leis a dtugadh siad ainm Bran air. Fuair an cú seo buaidh seilg air ariamh agus ní rabh le deánadh ag Fionn ach é a chur abhaile le sgéal dá mbéadh sé I gcruachas. An lá seo a chasadh Dearg Mór air bhí sé I gcruachas. Or bhí Dearg Mór I gheal é a mharbha. D’imithigh an cú agus níar stad sé go rabh sé ag an doras ag caislean na Feinne, agus sgairt ag an doras go gear. Bhí Gol mas Morna na shuidhe istuigh agus d’éirigh sé ór Saithin sé go rabh Fionn I gcruadhchas. Tharraing sé air a culaidh cruaidh cogaidh, le na leiní fhada ghuin, le na hata craoibhe craobha. Móran den óir buidhe sgriobha I n-árd leinidhc, gur be a bhí sgríobhcha ar lorg a sgeachain, fear bán na méala, fear a fathach chathaidh a léanadh long a a ndeichneabhair agus a chuirfeadh long aon duine isteach go doras na bruighthe. Throid sé fhéin agus Dearg Mór ar feadh naoí n-oidhche agus naoí lá agus ins an deireadh fuair Goll buaidh ar Dearg Mór.Deireadh.

4428299/4392571/4476296.title: Fionn Mac Cumhaill agus Cailleach na gCearc
4428299/4392571/4476296.text:
Lá amháin bhí Fionn Mac Cumhail amuigh a’ seilg agus casadh cailleach na gcearc dó. D’ fhiafruigh sí do Fhionn mbéadh cluiche aige, agus dubhairt Fionn nach rabh lá ariamh nac mbéadh. D’imir siad an cluiche agus cuir Fionn an cluiche uirthí. “Beir do breith anois, a Fhionn,” deir cailleach na gcearc. “Tá mé I n-am go leor,” deir Fionn. D’imir siad cluiche eile agus chuir cailleach an cluiche ar Fhionn. “Beir thusa do breith anois a chailligh,” ars Fionn. “Cuairim thusa faoi gheasa”, ars an cailleach, “agus faoi sláta druimed”. Bain do cheann agus do chosa agus do choimhead beatha fhéin  daodsa (díotsa) mar dtugaidh tú an seoirme ceann  an tairbh mhóir atá ina chodladh ins an domhain thoir. Cuirimse faoi (cleas ceadna duithe) deir Fionn, gabhail suas ar mullach an t-sean bhalla agus do aghaidh ar gaoith uaidh to ban muan. Breigheann an taobh daod (díot) agus rinne (punann) an choirce ar an taobh eile agus gan a dhath le h-íthe aicí go dtaradh seisean arais ach an méid a rachadh fríd cró suadadae. Nuair a fuair Fionn réidh d’imthigh sé a’ tharraing ar an domhain thoir. “Tóg thusa díom”, deir sí, “agus tógfhaidh mise daod”. Mo dhona agus mo dhorn ort, a sean calleach pisreoga, ma gnidhim”. D’imthigh Fionn annsin ag tarraing ar an domhain thoir agus shiubhal sé go dtáinig sé go beanna na fairrge. Annsin ní rabh fhios aige caidé bhí le deanadh aige na ní rabh long no bád le faghail ann.D’amharc sé síos agus connaic sé fear beag síos I n-iochtar a dtugadh siad “Troightha go leith fhear” air.
(continues on next page)

4428300/4392724/4476604.title: Story
4428300/4392724/4476604.text:
(continued from previous page)
At length the king got tired and told the man to take his daughter and be off that he would not be bothered (lor)  listening to him.



Once Finn challenged a Scotch Giant to fight him but the Scotch Giant was so terrible, so huge that Finn was frightened. He ran to the house and told his wife and she immediately thought of a plan. She had a huge cradle and fixed Finn into it. Soon the hero of Alban strolled in and in a thunderous voice demanded to see the Irish champion. Finn’s wife said that she couldn’t allow her domestic arrangements to be upset by international challenge fights so she packed him off to drag in some oak trees for firewood. “However” she says he won’t be long – sit down and rest your bones.” The stranger complied with her request and
(continues on next page)

4428303/4392926/4477562.title: Fionn Mac Cumhaill
4428303/4392926/4477562.text:
Chuir righ as Albain sgéal anonn chuig Fionn Mac Cumhail go rabh sé ag cur troda air. Bhí a háthair beo an t-am sin agus nuair a chonnaic sé é ag teacht chuir sí isteach sa chliabhán é. Nuair a tháinig sé isteach chuir sé ceist cá raibh Fionn. D’innis sí do go rabh sé amuigh ag seilg acht thaisbean sí an leanbh do.Nuair a chonnaic sé go rabh an leanbh comh mór sin shíl sé go rabh Fionn an mhór ar fad. Nuair a d’imthighs é amach rith sé an méid a bhí in a chnámha le bheith ar shiubhal sul a dtiocfdadh Fionn abhaile. Thosuigh Fionn agus a mháthair ag gáire nuair a smaointigh siad gur chuir sé eagla ar an righ a bhí comh mór le cúigear fear i gcuideachta a chéile, agus go rabh cár air a bhí comh mór le claoidheamh ar bith.



There was a poor man, who had thirteen sons. He had no food to give them, and he planned to leave them away in a wood. One of the sons name was Jack, and when he heard what his father was about to do he filed his pockets with pebbles.The father took them to a large wood, and when they were in the middle of the wood he left them. Jack had dropped a pebble here and there, so he knew the way back.The father then took them to a wood farther away. When they were leaving the house he gave each of them a piece of bread. Jack did not eat his, but dropped a crumb here and there. When they were in the middle of the wood the father left them.
(continues on next page)

4428266/4389835/4478188.title: (no title)
4428266/4389835/4478188.text:

Collector: Grace Campbell.Age: 10 years.Meenawilderg.Donegal P.O.



This is a story about Fionn Mc Cumhaill.Once upon a time Fionn Mc Cumhaill was hired with the King. The King used to put Fionn out every day to look after cattle that was out on a hill that was next to the palace. [Oo?] One day he went out and he saw a man coming towards him. When he was near him he knew that this man wanted to see him for something. Fionn was only small at the time and he got afraid when he saw the man coming because he thought he was going to kill him so he ran for his life to the palace. When he reached the palace he told the Queen his story and the Queen told him then that she would put him into a cradle and tell the man that it was a child of her own that was in it. So she done this. When the man came in he asked the Queen where was Fionn Mc Cumhaill. She told him that he was away hunting. He asked her then what was in the
(continues on next page)

4428281/4391450/4478791.title: Fionn Mac Cumhaill's Pond
4428281/4391450/4478791.text: Fionn Mac Cumhail was in the Croagh one day and he left the track of his heel in the mountains. The hole filled with water and it is known as “Fionn Mc Cumhail’s Pond”It is narrow at the bottom and wide as it comes up. It never fills to the top. There are two flat stones shaped like pans near by and they are called Fionn Mac Cumhail’s Pans. The story says that the giant used to make his bread in them.

4428287/4391982/4478857.title: Fionn agus Diarmuid i bParóiste Inbhir
4428287/4391982/4478857.text:
B'é Cormac Mac Airt an rí a bhí in Éirinn san treas aois. Fán am sin bhí na Fiana i mbláth. B'é Fionn Mac Cumhail an ceannaire a bhí ar na Fiana. Thug Cormac a inghean Aoife do Fhionn mar bhainchéile. B'fhearr le Fionn Gráinne, an inghean a ba deise. D'ealuigh sí le Diarmuid Ua Duibhne ceannaire eile a bhí ar na Fiana. B'éigean do Dhiarmuid agus Gráinne a theitheadh agus is beag áit in éirinn nár rinne siad stad agus mór chomhnuidhe ann.Nuair a bhí siad ar a dteitheadh chaith siad tamall i nGleann Éidhnighe, go dtí go bhfuair Diarmuid fios go rabh Fionn agus na Fiana ag tarraingt air. Chuaidh sé suas annsin go dtí Carnamhaoin, an áit a bhfuil leabaidh Dhiarmada agus Gráinne go fóill. Acht bhí fhios go maith ag Diarmuid nach ndéanfadh sin cúis dó, nó go gcognóchadh Fionn a ordóg feasa agus go mba heol dó nidh ar bith ar mhian leis. Sul a
(continues on next page)

4428309/4393632/4478971.title: Fionn Mac Cumhaill
4428309/4393632/4478971.text:
When Fionn Mac Cumhaill was living he was very good fighting. There was another giant in Scotland that challenged Fionn. Fionn told him to come to Ireland to fight, because he was afraid of him. Fionn had a big cradle made, and when the giant came he went into the cradle and his wife began to rock it.When the giant came in he asked where was Fionn, and she told him that he went up the hill there, and that he would soon be home again. When he was in the house a while he asked who was in the cradle and he was told that it was a young Fionn. Soon after that the baby began to cry, and
(continues on next page)

4428290/4392124/4479411.title: Scéal - Triúr Fear de na Fiannaibh
4428290/4392124/4479411.text:
SgéalTrúir fear de na FiannaibhAndrias Ua DomhnaillDíseartAois 13 blaidhnafuiar mé an sgeal seo anuraidh o Mícheal Ua DomhnaillDíseartAois 70 bliadhna26.7.'38Bí Fionn Mac Cumhaill agus Oisin Mac Fionn agus Goll Moirne triúr fear de na Fiannaibh amuigh ag reilg lá amháin agus bí dha madad leabhtha agus trí gunna. Druid an ceo isteach ortá agus níd nach iongnaidh  cuaidh siad as seachsan.Bál, rubhail siád leo agus fa deireadh conaic siad solas giotá fáda uabta agus tarraing siad air. Nuair a thainig siad comharach go-maith do, chonnaic siad go rabh se amuighar an oilean locha Cairn, Fuair siad bad, Cuaidh isteach ann agussiar go dtí an solas leobhtaí
(continues on next page)

4428297/4392383/4480608.title: Fionn Mac Cumhaill agus Cailleach na gCearc
4428297/4392383/4480608.text: Bhí Fionn Mac Cumhaill amuigh ag seilg lá amháin agus casadh Cailleach na gCearc air. Seo an rud a dubhairt Fionn leis. "Cuirimse fá gheasaibh agus sleata drama draoidheachta do cheann as do chosa do chóimhead a bheith ort fhéin go dtí an Domhain Thoir agus tug anoir ceann tarbh mire fhad liomsa." agus seo an rud a dubhairt Fionn Mac Cumhaill le Cailleach na gCearc. "Cuirimse fá gheasaibh agus sleata drama draoidheachta ban do cheann as do chosa do chóimhead a bheith ort fhéin as gan greim bidh no dighe agat acht Pionán Arbhar ar thaobh duit agus tubann bláth géar ort an múd a rachadh fríd cró snathaide go dtugfidh mise arais." "Tóg do gheasa díom" arsa Cailleach na gCearc le Fionn Mac Cumhaill. "Ní bhrisfidh mise m'fhocal na fhios gníodh tusa fadó shoir." D'imthigh Fionn leis go dtí an Domhain Thoir agus 'fhobhair go muirfeadh an tarbh mire é. Ghear sé an ceann de'n tarbh mire agus thug sé ceann an tarbh mire ionnus ar Cailleach na gCearc.

4428317/4394373/4480864.title: Fionn Mac Cumhaill i dTeamhair
4428317/4394373/4480864.text:
Bhí Fionn Mac Cumhail agus na Fianna ag cuir faobhtha i dTeamhair uair amhain. Cuaidh Fionn amach maidin amháin. Chuir sé a órdog in a bheal. Tháinig sé isteach arais. Dubhairt sé leis na Fianna go rabh triobloid mhóir riomhpa anois go cionn bliadhna. Chuaidh sé amach arais. Tháinig (sé isteach) bean mhór roimhe. Dubhairt an bhean leis go mairfeadh sí é mar bhfuighedh sé ceann Rí an Domhain Thoir dithe roimhe bliadhain ó. indiu. Tháinig sé isteach arais agus d’innis sé do na Fianna caidé mar bhí. Dubhairt na Fianna go gcaithfeadh Fionn a ghabhail ar shiubhal. Ní leigfeadh siad fear ar bith leis acht fear amháin. ‘Sé an tainm a bhí ar an fear sin. Tón Iariann gan Tapadh.D’imthigh Fionn agus Tón Iarainn leobhtha. Ní raibh siad i bhfad ag siubhal go bhfaca siad marcach ag tarraingt ortha. Dubhairt Fionn go gcuirfeadh sé ceilbhear ar an mharcach.
(continues on next page)

4428307/4393392/4481407.title: Fionn Mac Cumhaill
4428307/4393392/4481407.text:
Bhí fear ann i bhfad ó shoin darbh ainm Fionn Mac Cumhaill agus bhí mórán fear aige i gcomhnaidhe. Am amháin ní rabh mórán obair le déanamh aige agus chuaidh na fir uilig abhaile.Lá amháin bhí sé ag siubhal thart fá na páirceanna agus tháinig sé fhad le sean-bhean. Bhí an bhean ina suidhe ar chloch mhór i lár na páirce. Chuir an bhean ceist uirthí agus dubhairt sé "cé'n fá a bhfuil brón ort.""O, O" ars Fionn níl fear níl fear ar bith agam anois." "A" ars an bhean "ná beith brón ort agus tar annseo agus beidh imirt cairde againn."Thoisigh siad ag imirt agus bhí an buaiadh ag an bhean. Dubhairt an bhean "go gcaithfeadh seisean gabhail go dtí an Domhain Thoir agus ceann Cruaidh na gcrosánn a fhághail.
(continues on next page)

4428319/4394431/4481905.title: Scéal Fiannaíochta
4428319/4394431/4481905.text:
Sgéal Fiannaidheachta.Bhí fathach aon uair amhain i dTeidhleann agus bhí sé in a fhear án-mhór. Cualaidh muinntir Teidhleann iomradh go minic ar Cúchulainn. Bhí Cúchulainn le theacht chuca aon uair amhain le tamall a caitheadh leobhtha. Chualaidh an fátach i dTeidhleann go rabh Cúchulainn ina fear án – mhór ar fad agus bhí eagla mhór air. Nuair a bhí an fathach i dTeidhleann ag súil le na theacht chuir a bhean isteach i gcliabhan mhór é agus thosaigh sise ag bhogadh an cliabhain. Nuair a táinig Cúchulainn isteach damharc sé isteach sa chliabhan agus arsa seisean. “Is mór an leanbh sin atá agat. Cá bhfuil an fear é fhéin”? “Tá sé shuas ar Sliabh Liag ag seilg,” ars an bhean. Bhí sise ag leigint uirtí go rabh sé ar shiubhail agus é san cliabhán san am céadna. Bhí bunnóg mór aráin mhín cnuaidheamhail deánta aicí [muna]? choinne agus
(continues on next page)

4428319/4394434/4481908.title: Scéal Fiannaíochta
4428319/4394434/4481908.text:
(continued from previous page)
i dtolamh.Ach thug an ghasúr a fhocal do go ndeánfadh seisean coimhead ar a bhothan. Cúchulainn an t-ainm a tugtar air ariamh ‘na dhiaidh sin.



Pósadh Fhinn.Oidhche amháin bhí Fionn na luighe faoi chrann. Bhí Bran leis agus niorbhfada gur leig sé tamhthann. Léim Fionn na seasamh agus thainig beirt cailiní fhad leis. Bheannuigh Fionn dobhtha : “Cá h-ainm sibh” arsa Fionn. “Anna agus Déirdre”, arsa siadsan, “beirt inghean le Culann atá ionainn”, “Tainig muid a iarraidh ort duine againn a phósadh”. Dubhairt Fionn nach bposfadh sé ceachtar acu. Annsin dubhairt Deirdre gur de na sidheógaí í
(continues on next page)

4428348/4397881/4483614.title: Fionn agus an Bás
4428348/4397881/4483614.text:
Uair amháin bhí Fionn agus na Fianna amuigh ag seilg i gCo Chill Dara. Tháinig ceo ortha agus ní rabh siad i n-innibh a mbealach a dheanamh na bhaile. Chonnaic siad solus beag agus tharraing siad air.Bhí teach bréagh annseo agus bhí seandhuine na shuidhe ‘san choirneál. Bhí reithe mór ceangailte i gcionn an toighe. Chuir an seandhuine fáilte roimhe Fionn agus na Fianna agus d’iarr sé ortha fanacht go maidín.Shuidh na Fianna síos agus thoisigh Fionn agus an seanduine ag comhradh. Ní rabh siad i bhfad astoigh go dtáinic cailín óg anuas as seomra agus shuidh sí ar ghlúin an chéad
(continues on next page)

4428343/4397195/4485746.title: An Óige, an Saol agus an Bás
4428343/4397195/4485746.text:
Bhí sin ann ibhfad oshoin agus ibhfad oshoin fhéin é. Bhí na Fianna amuigh ag seilg lá amháin agus thainic seachran sealg agus ceó draoidheachta ortha. Shiubhal siad leóbhtha go dtainic an oidhche ortha agus gan fhios aca ca rabh siad ag dul.Anonn san oidhche tcí siad caochan beag soluis i bhfad uatha agus tarraingidh siad air. Ar theacht dóibh fhad leis an tsolus fuair siad amach gur teach a bhí ann agus an solus beag ag caocadh amach ar an fhuinneóig. Chuaidh siad thart fa'n teach ag cuartughadh an doruis ach chan fhuair siad é. Thart leó arís agus arís eile agus an tríomhadh uair ag dul thart dóibh fuair siad an dorus. Isteach leó.Bhí seanduine mór críon caithte cnámhach ina shuidhe ag an teine agus é ag amharc isteach san ghríosaigh. Bhí reithe mór ceangailte i gceann an tighe. Bhí seomra i gcúl na
(continues on next page)

4428346/4397544/4485979.title: Scéal Eile Fiannaíochta
4428346/4397544/4485979.text:
Scéal Eile FiannaidheachtaLá amháin bhí Fionn Mac Cumhaill amuigh ag seilg agus Conán Maol agus Diarmuid Ó Duibhne leis.Tháinig ceo orra agus shíl siad go mbeadh siad amuigh go maidin nuair a chonaic siad solas giota beag uathu agus tharraing air. Nuair a tháinig siad fhad leis an chaisleán chuaigh siad isteach. Bhí seanduine lom liath istigh agus d'éirigh sé agus chuir fáilte rompu, achan fhear ina ainm agus a shloinneadh.Bhí an-iongantas orra caidé'n dóigh a d'aithin an seanduine iad. Bhí cailín óg sgéimhiúil ins an chaislean fosda agus d'éirigh sise agus chuir céad fáilte rompu- achan fhear ina ainm agus a shloinneadh. Chuir sin tuilleadh iongantais orra uilig.Bhí créatúr beag áireachtach istigh fosta 'na shuidhe ag an teinidh agus d'éirigh seisean agus chuir seisean céad fáilte rompa - achan fhear ina ainm agus a shloinneadh. Bhí an-iongantas go deo orra uilig caidé'n dóigh a d'aithin an créatur sin iad.Shuidh siad thart ag comhrádh
(continues on next page)

4428356/4399060/4487132.title: Scéal
4428356/4399060/4487132.text:
(continued from previous page)
ar an fhear. Thoisigh an sagart a léigheadh as a leabhar agus thionntuigh an chaora ina sagart agus thoisigh an dá shagart a caint Laidine. " Geall ar Dhia arsa an fear "Cia bith atá sibh a rádh abairighidh amach go soileir é." Ins an bhomaite sin thionntuigh an sagart ina caora arais agus chuaidh sí isteach faoi'n bhéin lic, d'iarr an sagart ar an fhear a ghabhail isteach faoi'n lic agus í a thabhait amach chuaidh, ach ní rabh sí fághail aige. Agus, nuair nach rabh bhí a sháith iongantais ar an fear. Agus d'iarr an sagart air gan aon dhomhnach a leigint thart gan a gabhail 'un Aifrinn. D'imthigh an bheirt 'na bhaile agus ní fhacaidh aon duine an chaora on lá sin go dtí an lá indiú.Sgéalaidhe: Pádraig Ó Dubhthaigh Airdmhín Clochán Liath 65 bl.



Fionn Mac Cumhaill agus a Mhac OisínLá amháin bhí Fionn Mac Cumhaill agus na Fianna Éireann amuigh ag seilg. Chaith siad lá ar bheann is ar ghleann agus ní bhfuair siad dhath ar bith. Ag deireadh an tráthnóna agus iad ag teacht 'un an bhaile léim eilit mhaol amach as faoi bhun binne. Lean siad í
(continues on next page)

4428354/4398729/4487401.title: Fionn Mac Cumhaill
4428354/4398729/4487401.text:
There were two gangs of the Fianna. “The Mc Mornas and the “Clan a Blaoisigh. Fionn belonged to the Clann a Blaoisigh. The Mc Mornas killed the clann a Blaoisigh except Fionn McCumhaill’s father. He was the best man of the two sides.The king sent his daughter on the mountain to try to catch him. They set themselves on the mountain and he was two days with the kings daughter on the mountain. The people gathered on Fionn’s father and killed him.Nine months after there was a woman’s nurse to attend the king’s daughter as she was going to give birth to Fionn’s father. At that time they were able to foretell before the birth if the baby would be a boy or girl. It was foretold that this person was going to give birth to a son and daughter. The castle was built on the edge of the river. An old woman of the place told the nurse if a boy was born to throw him out of the window and she would be underneath to catch him. Then the nurse was to say that only a girl was born. The boy was born first and he was thrown out. Then the little girl was born. The old woman was waiting and took away the child.There was a big wood in the place. She went to a
(continues on next page)

4428354/4398733/4487402.title: Fionn Mc Cumhaill
4428354/4398733/4487402.text:
A king was in Ireland. He got married. When the boy was a year old his mother took very ill. She got worse and she sent for Fionn Mc Cumhaill. She asked him to take the boy and rear him if she would die until he would be 21 years and then he would reign as king.She died and Fionn took the boy and the king went to the Far East and married a sister of the High King (Árd Ri na Croise) she told him that this wee boy would become king when 21 years of age.She sent for Fionn. They had a great day drinking and sporting. It continued for a couple of days. Says the King’s wife to Fionn “What do you think if we would play a game of cards. Fionn consents. “Whatever I tell you do it” says she to Fionn “If I get the 1st three games, and whatever you tell me I’ll have to do it or I’ll be enchanted. (If you get the 1st three games.She got the 1st three games on Fionn. You’ll have to bring (Árd Rí na Croise’s head to me and give it to me in my arms” says she to Fionn.“We’ll play three more” says Fionn. Fionn got these three games. “You’ll have to go up on the top of the tower with a pot of water and a sheaf of corn and you aren’t to eat meat only what will
(continues on next page)

4428382/4402345/4493011.title: An Ghaeilge ar a Choigríoch
4428382/4402345/4493011.text:
(continued from previous page)

Agus ó tharla oiread airgid agam-sa iagus nach bhfeicim caithte go deo bhéarfaidh mé oiread airgid duit-se agus a thógfas tú fhéin agus do mhuinntie as an bhoichtineacht a choidhche agus é uilig siocair tú do theanga dílis a labhairt i bhfad ó bhaile. Thainic sé na bhaile arais chuig na mhuinntir agus bhí siad na dtrúir beo go sóghamhail ó sin amach.Domhnall Ó Domhnaill (Donnchadh)Rann na FeirsdeAois 40 bliadhainSiopadóir



Bhí Fionn Mac Cumhaill agus a mhór-bhalruigh amuigh ag seilg lá. Lá goirid geimhridh a bhí ann. Bhí spéarthaí troma ann agus neallta móra boga anuad ar bhárr na gcnoc. Le tuitim an tráthnóna mhéaduigh an ceo. Bhí sé comh dlúth ins na gleanntain agus nár léar duit an té a bhéadh ag do thaoibh. D'imthigh fear soir agus fear siar go dtí nár fágadh aon fear ag Fionn Mac Cumhaill ach Goll agus Oscar. Chongbhuidh an trúir acu fhéin greim láimhe ar a chéile ar fad. Shiubhail siad leo ag tuitim agus ag éirigh fríd na túrtógaí go dtí go rabh siad marbh sáruighthe. Thainic an oidhche ach níor corruigh an ceo. Chaill siad a n-uchtach mar shíl siad nach bhfeiceadh siad baile na áit a choidhche. Fá dherieadh chonnaic siad marbh sholas
(continues on next page)

4498088/4351343/4503164.title: Fionn agus an Chaoi a bhFuair sé Bean
4498088/4351343/4503164.text:
Lá amháin bhí Fionn agus na Fianna amuigh ag fiadhach. Chaitheadar an lá ar ghleann is ar bheann, ins na coilltibh, is ní bhfuaireadar aon nídh fós. Ins an tráthnóna agus iad ag teacht abhaile do dhúisigheadar eilith maol. Do leanadar í go dtí go rabhadar go léir tuirseach acht amhain Fionn agus a dhá mhadra Bran agus Sceolán. Do lean siad an eilith agus nuair a bhí siad i lár macaire móir agus an oidhche ag tuitim orra do stad an eilith. Thosuigh Bran agus Sceolán ag deanamh spóirt leis an eilith in ionad í do mharbh. Chuir sin iongnadh ar Fionn agus níor mhaith leis chuir isteach ar cor ar bith orra. Is minic do iompuigh sé chun dul abhaile .Bhí seacht uaire níos mó iongnadh anois air nuair a chonnaic sé an eilith dhá leanmaint agus ag déanamh spóirt le Bran agus Sceolán. Bhí Fionn 'na cómhnuidhe an uair seo cupla mile amuigh ó Cill Dara. Ní raibh se acht isteach in  párlús nuair a tháinig bean óg uasal isteach in diaidh. Ní raibh fhios ar Fionn cerbh' í.
(continues on next page)

4428381/4401977/4512363.title: Fionn Mac Cumhaill
4428381/4401977/4512363.text:
Lá amháin bhí Fionn Mac Cumhaill agus na Fianna amuigh ag fiadhach. Chaith siad an lá ar ghleann agus ar bheann, ins na coilltibh agus ar na bántaibh agus ní bhfuair siad a dhath ar b'fhiú labhairt air. Ag clapsolas agus iad ag teacht 'n-a bhaile dhúisigh siad eilit mhaol. Do lean siad í eadar fhir agus mhadaidh go dtí go raibh siad uilig tursach, sáruighthe, ach amháin Fionn agus a dhá mhadadh, Bran agus Sceolán.Do lean siad-san an eilit, agus nuair a bhí siad i lár machaire mór, agus an oidhche ag tuitim ortha, do stad an eilit. Tháinic Bran aghus Sceolán fhad leithe agus i n-áit an eilit a mharbhughadh mar ba' dual dóibh, 'sé an rud a thoisigh siad a dheanamh cuideachta agus a luascair thart 'n-a timcheall. Bhí iongantas an domhain ar Fhionn nuair a chonnaic sé caidé rinn na madaidh; níor mhaith leis cur isteach ortha
(continues on next page)

4428381/4402140/4512653.title: Fionn agus Fathach as Tír na Sorcha
4428381/4402140/4512653.text:
Bhí fathach 'n-a chomhnaidhe tall i dTír na Sorcha fad ó shoin, agus tháinic sé anall go hÉirinn.  'Sé an rud a thug anall é, bhí sé ag éisteacht le scealthaí éagsamhaltha fá fhear a bhí i Éirinn ar b'ainm do Fionn.  Bhí na daoine ag rádh go raibh Fionn 'n-a throdaidhe thar bárr agus nach dtiocfadh le fear ar bith láimh-an-uachtair a fhághail air.  Bhí an fathach seo iongantach maith ag troid fosta, agus duine ar bith a raibh sé ag troid leis fuair sé an bhuaidh air.Chuir an fathach scéala chuig Fionn ag inse do go raibh sé ag teacht agus nuair a fuair Fionn an scéala d'innis sé do n-a mhnaoi caidé 'n trioblóid a raibh sé ann.  Smaointigh sise sa bhomaite ar chlease.Bhí cliabhán mór sa teach agus an lá a riabh an fathach le teacht, chuir sí Fionn sa chliabhán.Nuair a tháinic an fathach 'am toighe chuir sé ceist ar bhean Fhinn cá raibh Fionn agus dubhairt sise go raibh sé amuigh ag seilg.  Chuaidh an fathach
(continues on next page)

4428398/4404398/4512759.title: Fathaigh agus Cailleacha
4428398/4404398/4512759.text:
Nuair a mhair Fionn Mac Cumhail annseo in Éirinn Bhí fáthach in Albain agus chuir fáthach na h-Alban troid ar Fhinn. Dubhairt Fionn go raibh seisean sásta go leór agus phioc siad lá na troda. Bhí eagla mhór ar Fionn agus smaointeadh siaid gur cheart cliamhan a dhéanamh do.Rinneadh cliamhan do agus nuair a tháinig lá na tróda, chuaidh Fionn isteach ann.  Níor b'fhada go bhfaca siad an fháthach ag teacht. Luighe Fionn go suaimhneach agus nuair a tháinig a fhathach isteach
(continues on next page)

4493626/4405456/4514207.title: Scéal - Fionn agus an Bás
4493626/4405456/4514207.text:
Fionn agus an BásBhí Fionn agus na fianna amuigh ag seilg la amháin i gCo. Cill Dara. Tháinigh ceo orcha agus ní rabh siad ábalta a mbealach a dheanamh na baile. Chonaich siad solus beag agus tarraingt siad air. Bhí teach ar bhreagh ann agus bhí reithe seanduine na shuidhe' sa' coirneal, agus bhí reithe mór ceangailte san ceann eile den teach.Cuir an seanduine fáilte roimhe Fionn agus a cuid fianna agus d'iarr sé ortha teacht tstrrach fanacht go maidin. Bhí fionn agus an seanduine ag comhnad agus bhí na fianna eile na shuidhe thart, thainig cáilín og anuas as an t-seomra, shuidh sí ar ghlún an céad fhear de na fiannaibh agus d'fiach seisean é a coinneacht ach ní rabh sé ábalta, annsin chuaidh sí fhadh leis an dara fear, ní rabh seisean abalta í a conghbhuilt ach oiread fa deireadh chuaidh sí fhadh le fiona é féin d'fheach seiseann í a conghbhuilt fosta ach sharuighairi agus d'imthigh sí suas chun t-seomra an
(continues on next page)

4428403/4404883/4514929.title: Story about Giants
4428403/4404883/4514929.text:
There once lived two families of giants, one in Dirralaghin which is about two miles from Losett School and the other in Tyrone. They wished to see which were the stronger and it was arranged that the Tyrone giants were to coe to Dirralaghin. There were seven giants in the Tyrone family and five in the Dirralaghin family. The Dirralaghin giants' father was dead but the mother was still alive. She was a very cute woman and when she heard of the coming of the Tyrone giants she got a few thin flat flags and rubbed soft oat meal over them and left them by the fire to dry. She then put the eldest son in the cradle, the second son to herd the cattle and sent the other three to shoot deer.The Tyrone giants arrived that day as they had arranged and the old woman came out to welcome them. She asked them if they would like to come in and have some dinner. She said her men folk were not at home and that she was very sorry. She insisted them to remain as her men would be back again in a few days.She told one of the Tyrone giants to go up
(continues on next page)

4493732/4414909/4529054.title: Paidir le Ráit ag Gabháil ar Aistear
4493732/4414909/4529054.text:
Once upon a time there lived in Gartan a man named Fionn Mac Cumall and he was a giant and there was another giant in Scotland. The giant in Scotland. The giant in Scotland heard how brave the other man was and said that he would go over and fight him. Fionn Mac Cumall heard that he was coming and he went home to ask his wife for a plan. She was a giant and she told him to go into the cradle and to let on that
(continues on next page)

4493794/4421188/4537812.title: Fionn Mc Cool's Stone
4493794/4421188/4537812.text: Fionn McCool was supposed to be a very famous man. There is a stone in Bulba in a place they call "Corr a Bheag" and it is said that Fionn McCool threw it at a dog from the top of Bulaba down to "Corr a Bheag". The stone to look at is about ten tons weight or more.

4493794/4421254/4537901.title: Fionn Mc Cool's Rock
4493794/4421254/4537901.text:
In Maghermore hill there is a large stone. Fionn McCool was supposed to have thrown this stone from Bulba hill to this place with his left hand. It is said he was looking for some place and he passed a large crowd of men trying to move this stone out of their way. Fionn saw them and he was mounted on his horse. He bent down from his horse and lifted the heavy stone with his left hand that the crowd of men couldnt lift.He left the tracks of his five fingers behind him and they are plain to be seen on the rock.
(continues on next page)

4493811/4422845/4538652.title: A Funny Story
4493811/4422845/4538652.text:
Once upon a time there lived a giant in this district.  He was a very cross giant and he made all the people who lived round him do what he told them.He lived at the top of the hill and at the foot of this hill there lived a poor man and his wife.  The giant made this woman bake bread and kill her best fowls for him to eat.  At last the man got tired of this and one day the giant came down for bread and the man refused to give it to him.  The giant was in a great rage at this and he said he would come down in the evening and if he would not give him bread he would punished.When the evening came the giant came down to the man's house.  The woman saw him passing the window and she told the man to get into the cradle and pull the clothes over him.  The man did this.  The giant came to the door
(continues on next page)

4566077/4564848/4572691.title: Story
4566077/4564848/4572691.text:
My father, Martin Mannion, of Fairfield, about one mile north of Aughrim, told me this story.  He is aged about fifty two or three years.      Cuchulain and Ferdiad were two strong men that lived in Ireland long ago.  Those two men were married.  They were living a short distance away from each other.      Ferdiad's wife did not like Cuchulain at all.  She had some grudge or other against him.  She was continually asking her husband to give him a sound thrashing, but Ferdiad was afraid of Cuchulain.      At length and at last, he took courage and set out for his neighbour's house.  Cuchulain's wife saw Ferdiad coming.  She knew well that this man was able to beat her husband and he knew it too.      "Here is Ferdiad coming.  I wonder what is he looking for.  I suppose he is looking for a fight.  That wife of his is a holy fright" said Cuchulain's wife.  Cuchulain looked at the door, and at the window, and saw that there were no means of escape.      "Here, jump into the cradle, and I'll put the clothes about you" said his wife.  In he got, and made himself comfortable.  Now Cuchulain's
(continues on next page)

4583335/4580652/4587484.title: Fionn and the Salmon
4583335/4580652/4587484.text:
Fionn and the salmon.During the time of the Fianna there was man named Fionn captain of the Fianna.  Many strange tales are told of how Fionn got his knowledge and here is one.It happened that a man named Finnegas was teaching Fionn beside the river Boyne. One while they were sitting beside the bank they saw a large salmon floating in the water.  Finnegas knew that this fish was the salmon of knowledge.They he told Fionn to catch the fish and cook it and bring it to him but not to eat any of it until he tasted the fish first.Fionn did as he was told.  He caught the fish and put it on the fire to cook but when he was turning it he burned his thumb and immediately put it in his mouth to ease the pain.
(continues on next page)

4602699/4596290/4606646.title: Fionn bFearra
4602699/4596290/4606646.text:
(1)Go deirneach ins an oidce le linn mé a goil comh suimnis do cualas torran binn ag gol timceall ins an tsrád.Cé'r bhiongnad domsa liongrad Nuair a shiubal sé áill go dtí mé mar bhí mé féin lán cinntí gur b'é Fionn bfearra a bhí ann.(2)So ceist am orth le fuillsgte cé'r bas anois a ghluais tú ag teact faoi mo fuairim siubal oidce tríd an snám Nó ar duine dfág an saogal tú a tá Ruigte o do muinntir má tá tú ag iarraig dideann suid sios go dfuigte an lá.(3)Ní duine dfág an saogal mé act geasgac atá faoi draoict mé thoid mé an cú lioffa an crán agus an tál. Tá mainm le fáigil ithiosad i stár na hÉireann Sgriobfa go bé Fionn a rinnead Rig dhium ar suige croic Meado.
(continues on next page)

He was very wise for he went to school to Finnegas who was a poet  and there is a little story  told about it.When Fionn was going to school at the Boyne there was a Salmon of Knowledge in it, and it was said that (there was a Salmon of) whoever would taste a piece of it, would be very wise. One day Finnegas caught the Salmon and he told Fionn to roast it but not to taste it. Fionn roasted it but when he was turning it a piece stuck to his finger, and he put his finger in his mouth. He then brought the Salmon to Finnegas and Finnegas asked him did he taste it, Fionn told him that he did not, but when he was

4649686/4646928/4650111.title: The Giant
4649686/4646928/4650111.text:
The Giant."Long, long ago a great giant called MacHugh lived at Sheemore. He used to travel North, South, east and west, robbing the people and bringing home their cattle and their food to provide food for himself and his wife. One morning when he got up from bed he went down to the bottom of the hill and lifted a big rock from the bottom of the hill and flung it from him and it fell six miles away, and the place where it fell was ever afterwards called "Shee beig." There is a lough where he lifted the rock from. He used to step across to Scotland and rob and plunder there as well as at home. One day he took another giant's property in Scotland. The giant was angry
(continues on next page)

4672109/4671094/4678964.title: Finn Mac Cool in the Valley of Masshill
4672109/4671094/4678964.text:
Long, long ago in Eire there was a mighty army known as the Fenians. The captain of the army was one Finn Mac Cool who often visited and chased the deer on the Ox Mountains.Once Finn and his army were marching along the Ox Mountains. There was a huge rock in their way. One of the men hit his head on this huge rock. Finn took up the rock and fired it. It fell outside "Glen" wood. It is called "Carraig an Eanaigh" or the "Rock of the Eanagh". There is the print of the man's head in the rock. It is remarkably  huge rock standing alone in the middle of the "eanagh".
(continues on next page)

Is gearr go bfeaca sé chuige isteach ón bhfairrge fear mór árd ná raibh ach an Fhairrge Mhór ag dul suas thar osgal a chos agus thar na raghadh pláta stáin idir  é agus an spéir. " Cad é an cúram atá agatsa dos no Fianna", arsa Fionn.  "Tá", arsan Fathach, "go dtabhrfainn ón bhFéin liom".  "Cad é an cómhacht atá

422Fionn Mac Cumhail agus an Grúgach  Bhí bean ann fadó.  Bhí beirt mhach aici.  Cúpla do beadh iad.  Ba mór lei an trioblóid a bhí sí ag fágháilt uatha.  Lá amháin buaileadh isteach ina h-aigne go mbearr iad a bháth.  Dhein sí dhá chiseán agus chuir sí  leanbh isteach ins gach ceann.  Leig sí síos leis an abhainn iad.  Bádhadh duine aca ach d'fhan ciseán amháin ar bhárr an uisce.  Lá amháin bhí bean ag siúbhal ar bhruach na h-abhann tamall maith ón áit nar chaith sí isteach iad.  nuair a connaic sí ciseán ar bharr an uisce agus leanbh istigh ann.  Tháinigh iongnadh uirthi.  Thug sí abhaile é agus d'fhás sé suas ar nós aon bhuachaill eile.  Bé sin an leanbh go dtughtar Fionn Mac Cumhail anois air.  I naois seacht

Do stad sé agus sar a raibh fios ag an mbuachaill cé bhí ann, bhí greim ar cluais ag an sagart air.     " An mó dia ann a dhailtín? arsan sagart." 4701696/4693498/4727672.title: A Funny Story
4701696/4693498/4727672.text:
Long ago there lived in Ireland a great giant, and he had defeated all that challenged him to lose. At that time also there lived a King in Spain, and he sent word to him that he was coming to fight him. This Irish giant was married to a woman that was very clever, and as the Spanish King came unexpected she put him into a big cradle, and covered him. He sat down beside the cradle, and asked was the giant himself at home. Then the woman told him that he would be home in an hour. Then he asked what age was the child, and she said that he was just three months. The giant then began to think to himself that when the child three months was that big the giant himself must be an awful size. Just then he began to get hungry, and she sent him out for a bullock. He went up the hills for the bullock, but the herds-men would not let him take him. So he caught holt of one horn, and they caught the other, until they tore him in two. Then he brought in half the bullock and roasted it. The woman made a cake, and she put lime in the middle of it. When it was baked she gave it to him to eat, and it was as hard as he broke his teeth trying to eat it, but he didn’t like to say that he couldn’t eat Irish bread. After he had enough of this eaten, he went out to a stream for a drink, and the woman followed him. The water was flowing down and the woman went
(continues on next page)

4723817/4716053/4743423.title: Scéalta a Bhaineas le Stair - The Gallows Hill
4723817/4716053/4743423.text:
(continued from previous page)
The Gallows hill is situated at the end of the town of Carrickmacross. On this hill stands a tower made of stone and thickly covered in ivy. It is said that people were hanged there long ago. Others say there was meal ground there in olden days.



There is a large rock, shaped like a chair, in Shirley's demesne called Fionn MacCool's chair.It is said that was Fionn's resting place. It is said that anyone that sits on it can make a wish. Many people go to see this chair.
